p: West Nile Virus is among the most common mosquito-borne viruses in the U.S., and there is currently no vaccine for it. Only about 20 % of those bitten by virus-loaded mosquitoes develop fever, body aches, headache, and nausea. Another 1 % develop neurological problems that can be serious. Humans are a “dead-end” host for the virus, in that it is not transmitted further. The virus is predominantly found in birds (see http://www.cdc.gov/westnile/resources/pdfs/Bird%20Species%201999-2012.pdf), which lists those species in which the virus is found (Fig. 2.15).
